# Goal
- Given a slicing tree, output the minimum size of floor planning.
- ![https://i.imgur.com/hSRkOea.png](https://i.imgur.com/hSRkOea.png)

# Idea
- For 2 child with dimension $(h_l, w_l)$ and $(h_r, w_r)$
- For vertical node(eg. 1, 5 in the figure above)
	- $D = (width_1 + width_2, max(height_1, height_2))$
- For horizontal node(eg. 2, 8 in the figure above)
	- $D = (max(width_1, width_2), height_1 + height_2)$

# Algorithm
- Objective
	- Left child with dimension $(h_l, w_l)$
	- Right child with dimension $(h_r, w_r)$
	- List $L = \{(h_l, w_l), (w_l, h_l)\}$ sort by the first or second element.
	- List $R = \{(h_l, w_l), (w_l, h_l)\}$ sort by the first or second element.
- For vertical node
	- $L, R$ sort by the first element
	- Like merge two sorted list
		- $l = l_1, r = r_1$
		- if $l.second > r.second$ , then $l = l_{next}$
		- if $l.second < r.second$ , then $r = r_{next}$
		- if $l.second = r.second$ , then $l = l_{next}, r = r_{next}$
	- It will generate a dimension list $D$ contain multiple dimension combination.
	- With $D = (width_1 + width_2, max(height_1, height_2))$
- For horizontal node
	- Like above, but with $D = (max(width_1, width_2), height_1 + height_2)$
	- Like merge two sorted list
		- $l = l_1, r = r_1$
		- if $l.first > r.first$ , then $l = l_{next}$
		- if $l.first < r.first$ , then $r = r_{next}$
		- if $l.first = r.first$ , then $l = l_{next}, r = r_{next}$
- Now we know the total floor planning area by bottom-up the slicing tree.
- To get the location of each node in the slicing tree, traverse the slicing tree top-down.
